newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: FOCUS-Credit Suisse plunges into 1996 loss.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Credit Suisse plunges into 1996 loss.

text.p: Credit Suisse Group said on Wednesday it plunged to a 1996 net loss of 2.59 billion Swiss francs ($1.7 billion) due to extraordinary charges of 5.4 billion for restructuring and providing for bad loans.
But based on what Credit Suisse described as "a gratifying start to the current year," the bank's management decided to pay out an unchanged dividend of four francs per share.
"The year 1997 has begun positively, and we are therefore very confident of our ability to reach the goals we have set," the company said in a statement.
Lukas Muehlemann, the new chief executive hired from Swiss Reinsurance, told a news conference that Credit Suisse expected structural improvements in its earnings during 1997.
"For the current year Credit Suisse Group expects structural imporvements in earning power throughout the group and, in particular, in Swiss business," he said.
Shares in Credit Suisse, firmed in early trading on the Swiss Exchange by 2.25 francs to 160.75.
Although the loss was larger than expected, dealers said the outlook seemed positive.
Credit Suisse, along with Switzerland's two other major banks, Union Bank of Switzerland and Swiss Bank Corp., last year changed their method for calculating provisions for loans.
Swiss banks have been hard hit by the long-running downturn in the Swiss economy and have had to write-off billions of francs in bad loans in recent years.
Credit Suisse also embarked on a large-scale restructuring that involved dropping the name of CS Holding from the group and creating four new operational units.
The 1996 net loss is slightly larger than the 2.1 billion franc loss Credit Suisse forecast last year when it announced it was changing its method for calculating credit risks.
The difference is due to a 195 million franc increase in general reserves for banking risks as well as a decision not to activate 170 million in U.S. losses for tax purposes.
Apart from the extraordinary charges, Credit Suisse's operating results last year improved slightly with pre-tax operating profit rising three percent to 2.47 billion francs.
Gross earnings from normal banking business rose 17 percent to 12.89 with trading income soaring 33 percent to 3.9 billion.

Profits from trading such instruments as currencies, shares or metals accounted for roughly one-third of total gross earnings while interest business accounted for 27 percent. ($ = 1.481 Swiss Francs)
